subject: Art
title: Baseline & X-Height
description: The invisible lines that define how type sits and how tall it appears.

hook.text: All letters sit on an invisible line â€” the baseline. But the lowercase 'x' height varies dramatically between typefaces. Two fonts set at the same size can look completely different. X-height is why.

buildup.text: The baseline: where letters rest (like the floor). X-height: the height of lowercase 'x' (the body of lowercase letters). Cap height: top of uppercase letters. Ascender: parts extending above x-height (b, d, h). Descender: parts extending below baseline (g, p, y).

discovery.text: Large x-height = letters appear bigger and more readable at small sizes (great for screens, UI). Small x-height = more elegant, more contrast between upper and lowercase (great for print, editorial).

twist.text: This is why 12pt Verdana looks much larger than 12pt Garamond â€” Verdana has a much larger x-height. Point size measures the font's em square, not the visible letter height. Two 12pt fonts can appear wildly different in size.

climax.text: When choosing body text fonts, compare their x-heights. For screen readability, lean toward larger x-heights. For print elegance, consider smaller x-heights with more prominent ascenders and descenders.

punchline.text: Point size is a lie. X-height is the truth about how big type actually looks.

quiz.question: Why can two typefaces at the same point size appear different in size?
options: Different x-heights â€” the height of lowercase letters varies between typefaces
